I thought I should probably write a review about one of my favorite series' that i've ever watched. Since it's been a while since I watched the first and second seasons, i'll start off with a review about the third season. Please keep in mind this is just my opinion
Story:
Where the first and second season completely set up an amazing story, I think the third season just came off as a disappointment to me, i've watched the first and second season of Shakugan no Shana 2-3 times, and I have to say the story is almost a masterpiece, and I expected much more from thethird season than what it gives us. I'll avoid giving spoilers, but it comes out with some developments that don't exactly make sense or fit into the story whatsoever, the first few episodes have little to no meaning when we look at the overall story. Also, I think they made the antagonists overly weak in the third season, I was expecting to see some like super-powerful opponents, but I was greatly disappointed, nothing like watching the first season and seeing the protagonist have trouble. 


Art: 

The art didn't really change, I thought the first and second season's art were masterpieces, so they stuck to it, and it still works.

Sound:

In my opinion, Shakugan no Shana uses some of the best soundtracks that are fitting to the anime. From the opening (Light my Fire - KOTOKO) to the ending (I'll Believe, One - ALTIMA) Shakugan no Shana utilizes some of the best songs in Japan i've ever heard. So I believe it deserves a 10/10 in the sound department.


Character:

Eh, where the first and second season always made great developments of character, the third season didn't really bring anything special. There wasn't any real character development and it sort of just went off the flow that the second season set for it. 


Enjoyment:

As a fan of the Shana series, I couldn't bring myself to hate this anime, with all its shortcomings, I would still give it 9/10 in enjoyment, but I have to say from an objective point of view, it was disappointing.


Overall:

If this anime was a standalone anime, maybe it would score higher, but going off the great momentum the first and second season built for it, I think it was just disappointing to me, and maybe ending it at the second season was the best way to go. I agree that the way the writer ended this series was heartwarming, but the way the series got to the end was disappointing. Overall, i'd definitely give it 7-8/10 and that's being generous because i'm such a big fan of the series.

I must say. I was kind of dissappointed with season 2 of this show. However season three saved it for me. I would like to point out that this show has a very different feel than the other two seasons. If you only saw season 3, then you would be like, "what the heck is going on," while watching one or two. The dramatic change between seasons two and three, is a very welcome change, as it removes the staleness of the show. highly recommended

Content:
At first I was pretty disappointed by the sudden plot reversal after season 2, since I was enjoying the first two seasons so much. Season 3 was just so vastly different from the previous seasons that it almost felt like I was watching a different anime. Despite this, the story was very well executed. I found myself constantly questioning everything: is ___ really telling the truth? Who's right and who's wrong? Who is acting deliberately and who is being mislead? What is ___'s real goal? And most of all, what is right and what is wrong? This anime is among the best I've watched inthat regard, but because of the slow progression and the total 180 from the previous two seasons I have to knock a couple points off. Score: 7/10


Animation:

There wasn't anything special about the peaceful scenes, but the fight scenes were spectacular. There was so much stuff going on that it really made me feel in awe of the fighters. However, what really set this anime apart from others is that you could always tell exactly what was going on despite the massive content, unlike many others where the action scenes end up being utter chaos. Additionally, I appreciated the way CGI was used pretty much exclusively for the robots. Score: 8/10


Music:

There wasn't anything unique about the soundtrack, but it was very well done. Some kind of background music was present most of the time, and it always fit the scene and set the atmosphere very well. I would give the soundtrack an 8 if it weren't for the little jingles that play before and after commercial breaks. They weren't nearly as annoying as they were in the previous two seasons, but they were still irksome. Score: 7/10


Character:

This anime does not have great character development. It's not terrible, but there's nothing special, and if anything I'd say it was subpar, considering how little the main characters developed and how long it took them to do so; it was often hard to tell that anything changed until the very last episode. HOWEVER. This anime did something spectacular in the way that it effortlessly built characters and communicated their personalities without spending much time dedicated to each of them. There is some screentime dedicated to the backstories of a couple of the main characters, which is nothing special. It's the minor characters that set this anime apart. The number of characters with no solo screentime, who only play supplementary roles, is abnormally large in this anime, and yet I felt like I knew each of them personally just through their actions and behaviors that were displayed in the background of the main characters' endeavors. I have to knock two points off for the terrible development of the main characters, but this anime really did something special in this regard. Score: 8/10


Enjoyment and overall:

I have to give this anime a 6 for enjoyment, just because I was disappointed by the plot shift and a little frustrated at times with how slowly things were progressing. However, this season did a lot of things very well, and it could easily deserve an 8 or even a 9 for reasons discussed. I decided to lowball it a bit since I personally didn't find the whole as enjoyable as the sum of the parts. Score: 7/10

Well, in spite of others saying this season is confusing and yes indeed it is, but I think that adds to the mystery and slowly watching throughout the season, pieces come to together to help with the confusion later in the series. I must say the never ending 'ending' feel of it keeps me watching and wondering: When will all of this end? The only part that I do not fully understand is how Yuuji came to find the Snake of the Festival and their encounter. Although it briefs and it says Yuuji's motives are to make a peaceful world where Flame Hazes no longerhave to fight and so he can live with Shana, this part confuses me and makes me believe the Snake is deceiving him only to use him as a vessel for his existance until his body is rendered stable again. The goal of Yuuji is somewhat clear to me, but at the same time not as he constantly fights with Shana who is contempt to her own ways, despite his sincereity for doing all this for her. Overall I think a couple more episodes could have been added to the beginning to help tie some loose ends and clarify how all this came to be. But if you really enjoy the series like I do, all confusion will start to unravel itself in time.


Story: 9 Since the introduction is yet to fully clarify itself. However the rest of the plot unravels itself throughout the season.


Art: 10 I have to say the art in this anime is spectacular. In my own opinion. it's not dull and a lot of effects and quality character designs.


Sound: 10 The music really gets you in the mood and the effects of fighting and magic are also quite unique.


Character: 9 With the lack of clear character motive in the begining and somewhat throughtout the season, I feel Yuuji's character drastically changed without a clear reason and cause. Sure he met the Snake of the Fesitval and whatnot and wants to free Flame Hazes, but his past character wouldn't have aggreed to go against Shana. However, his kindness and desire to help others can also contradict this as he says he IS fighting for Shana's freedom.

On the other hand, supporting characters such as Margery and Sauto's development has finally reached a point where... 


***(SPOILER)***

They finally realize eachothers feelings for eachother.


And the fact that Tanaka has resolved to not being part of the world of Crimson Lords and such anymore and stays behind with Ogata to be by her side.


Enjoyment: 10 The seemingly never endless conclusion carries throughout the season. The season could have ended within the first few eps, and again in the middle of the season. But it kept on trucking and the final revelation is yet to be seen. Thus keeps me interested in what will happen next and is this finally it? A unique strategy that only a few anime can pull off and STILL leave enjoyment for the viewer instead of it seemingly repeating itself.


Overall: 9. It was really close to a perfect score. But a few flaws and lack of clearance has left me with a feeling of 'emptiness' on the situation in the begining and still kinda feel it.

Okay, as always I want to preface my review with the three things I’m looking for in an anime: I want a really good story (+5), I want really good dialogue (characters/character development, etc.)(+3), and I want really good “technicals” (style, sound, etc.)(+2). Also, I’ll remind you my reviews generally encompass the whole series of an anime unless otherwise stated (That is to say that no more seasons are coming out). So let’s get to it!
Shakugan no Shana… I feel that this anime had an enormous amount of potential. With a story revolving around the competing ’existences’, i.e. Flame Hazes vs. Crimson Denizens, who resideon different planes of reality, the show hit’s the ground running with a really cool premise. Think about it, battles going on in an unseen world that you’ll never know about, yet the outcomes of which could and does effect your life in unimaginable ways. So much so that you could just be written out of existence! This was going to be the tragic fate of our protagonist, however, as it just so happens he’s not your everyday human. The story continues with his adventures trying to figure out his place now that this whole new unseen reality has been revealed to him. To me, that’s a goldmine of possibilities set up to work with. 


Earning 4 points 


However, the ending of this anime decides to throw all that in the garbage. Nearly the entirety of the last season is a mess of epic proportions. Instead of continuing with all the good things the first seasons had built up, the last season goes on its own into the wilderness of horrible endings. By introducing practically a whole new cast of characters, creating nonsensical plot drivers, and just plain ridiculous reasoning by the characters in terms of their decision making faculties, Shakugan no Shana goes out in a pyre of infamy. Frankly, I’m going to be watching it to appear on some top ten list of “Most Unexpected Anime Endings”, because I found it hard to swallow that something so good could become so bad.


Deduction: -1.5 points

----------------------------


As for the dialogue and character development, I was quite pleased for the most part. The interactions and relationship between the protagonist and Shana were well executed and all in all, the characters were enjoyable. The romantic elements were handled to my liking, and, the protagonist does grow throughout the story as a character (as does Shana). There are some characters (especially towards the end) that are left high and dry in the character development department, but, all main characters have enough in my humble opinion to allow the story to progress relatively unhindered. 


Earning 2 points

---------------------


Technicals are solid. I truly enjoyed the entire OST of this anime, the style and animation were good too. No complaints.


Earning 2 points  

---------------------


Bonus points award goes to… having some really cool Flame Hazes out there! And some cool powers to come with them! 


Earning 1 point. 

--------------------


Add it all up and we have a score of 7.5! If you want my advice, just watch the first two seasons only, then let your imagination make up what’s going to happen next. It’ll be better that way. Trust me, if I had done that, this anime would have been an 8.5 easy.


As always, since I’m a critic, I’ll round down my score to a 7 because that’s just the way it goes. That way it’ll be better than expected when you watch it! Till next time

This is more of a comparison than a review (not following the usual format).
Shakugan no Shana III is very different from the previous two seasons. It might throw many fans under the truck. The plot is twisted and a ton of new characters and rules appeared.  The anime did a poor job explaining them all (you will have to do some extra reading). There is a lot more fighting and less drama in this season. It can pretty stand by itself, in which case I would give it a 6/10. However, consider the development of other two; I gave all 3 seasons an 8/10.\n
*Spoiler:  The third season suffers a common “disease”- mess up power scale. Yuuji becomes a god, yet he remains surprisingly weak. He is even weaker after recovered the god’s body?!?  On contrary, Shana becomes ridiculously strong “sometimes” –  she can barely beat normal Denizens in the other two seasons, but now she kicks Yuuji (the strongest God)’s ass ?!? \n
A major flaw: Why are they fighting all the time? Both sides could have easily negotiated, since Denizens’ goal is to make another world for themselves. If not, right after the crushing victory, Denizens could have asked for peace. Yuuji banned eating humans, but he didn’t attempt a peace treaty? Yuuji could have told Shana about his plan and started the negotiation at any time. Yet they fought until the end, Yuuji was fixing the city—he was saving lives for god sake, but Shana fought him anyway?!? \n
Season 3 motto is “kill first talk later”.  \n

And thus we came to the third and final season and from which I was able to draw the fact that Shakugan no Shana is my favourite anime series of all time.
Where do I begin...
Yuuji disappeared after the final battle as Yoshida and Shana waited for him to see who he loved.
Puzzled, Shana decides to scour the city in the hope of finding him but it was as if he'd disappeared off the face of the Earth. In reality...
Yuuji had decided to side with the enemy. This was puzzling to me as I thought, him and Shana had been fighting the Crimson Denizen together forso long and had started to develop feelings for one another and now he's upped and left? Not to mention that he was helping the Crimson Denizen with their ultimate plan of creating a new world. \n\n
The battles, new characters, the twists and turns, the new powers Shana gained in her quest to get her man back and the sacrifices that were made all culminated to what was a nice ending to a series that I thought would be a run of the mill action romance series. \n\n

This one took me a while to finish, which has been unusual for me and an anime for a long time. This review of the series as a whole, although I will be focusing mostly on the final season.
Watching the first two seasons, I found myself enjoying Shakugan no Shana very much. The story and character development, along with the romantic tones, were very well structured. It was something I was hoping for in this anime, and it lived up to my expectations quite well.
The third season, however, changed this, if only a tad. The random change to Sakai Yuji's position in the show wasnot only very unexpected but was something I rather disliked. I found myself halfway through the season and extremely bored at times. I actually ended up only watching a single episode, if that, when I went to watch.


Towards the end of the final season I still found myself bored at times but it became far more enjoyable. The final few episodes made for a great end to the series, with large battles, the defeat of some really annoying characters (The Professor for example) and a resolution to the lover's quarrel between Yuji and Shana in the final moments of the final episode. The final two episodes unexpectedly became a huge redeemer to my overall disappointment in the final season. 


I would highly recommend this show to anyone willing to watch. If you prefer to skip out on the frustration of the final season, the end of the second season is almost a perfect place to stop. That being said, I'm a guy who likes to see things to the end if I can.


First season: 8/10


Second season: 8/10


Third season: 7/10 (It would honestly rank as a 6.5, but I prefer whole numbers)

Well, I'm not certain why I'm writing this or if I should do it, I'm probably just being selfish but anyway I'll do it. I hope someone enojy reading this tought I just want to express some feelings I had as a true fan who watched Shakugan since season one and waited years, prayed to God for season 3 to come, and that the tsunami hadn't killed the show's cast. After that, I got really, really excited when I heard the rumors that it would come out. I waited for really long. This series was my top rating series ever. I can't describe the feelingthis series gave me, because since I watched my 50th anime, I don't get them anymore for a unknown reason. The thing is, when the official anouncement came, I was hardly happy. Why? You tell me. Maybe I waited for too long? I watched it anyway, hoping the final season would bring me the feelings I had long experienced. I am aware about the actual quality of Shakugan's plot since the start of it and I'm aware it is not top notch. But what I got from the final season was mediocre seinen. Even with most struggle I can't build a logical thinking about the build of the plot. It is just bad. I know maybe I'm digging too deep to find things that are hardly found in anime, but then it makes Shakugan no Shana Final just another anime. Season 3 is about a fake emotional struggle, where the main characters create a war where most people say that love or saving the world can explain it in some way. If it is centered on changing the world, it has no sense together with the show's circunstances. If it's about love, it's even more stupid. The only way I can see it is the lack of creativity from the creators. All that summarizes this final season is the kiss in the very last minute of the anime, something every fan really waited for long enough. Actually, this season could have been really good if the protagonist motives were just evil, or if the character made explicitely human mistakes. The nature of a thinking being was incredibly distorted in a way that happens in most fantasy themes, where they just stop following logic or, they lose their brains and start acting like dolls controlled by an umature person who can only see the ending, in this case, the final kiss, whitout caring about the present of the story. Because even the final minutes where typical nonsense, stuff that would only be interesting if in a show ironizing and criticizing the way most animes are poorly done, like with "epic" senseless battles and weird cuteness or polictical bs and random people dying, like those things, just for themselves, make it good. I really wish I didn't think like this. I wait months or years now for a good anime to come, with some very rare ocasions where I find one that is entertaining. The good this is the anime industry is not the only place where you can find good stories, well, this is almost a stupid thing to write. Going back to Shana, no, it didn't make me feel like the first two seasons did, Even more, it made me look back to my past and see that I wouldn't enjoy them also, with the stardards I carry today. The thing is, this isn't a bad anime, when compared to most anime. You can certainly enjoy it, and feel like I did in the past. I can't even described the feelings. I don't like saying this, but its the damn truth, all anime watchers around hate hearing. Growing up. People mature in different ways from each other. At least thats what I think from my experiences. Some people will get more serious like me, and I gotta tell you it really sucks lol. Other will forever see the comedy and fun of watching nonsense. And it's not sush a bad thing. It's selfish of me to wish that all animes made out there fit my taste. But this one really hit my personal feelings. Yeah I'm this weird. Enjoy. Overall, I was really touched by this series, for some reason, but after years, it now sucks, and, even if I will never trully know, I think this is the worst season of them all. Love is the most powerfull spell, and it also makes animes look better than they are. Like with everything in life. So love everything and be the happiest person ever.

Compared to the last season, Shakugan no Shana Final starts right where it ends: With Yuki Sakai meeting Shana and Kazumi in his answer. But in the moments before he chooses Shana, he disappears. What became of him? Why is everyone forgetting him?
The Story:
Packs a punch just like the last season. Voice acting in the Funimation Dub was superb.  Shana's journey comes to a close with the battle of her life. 
Moments to Look Forward to:
-Margery Daw's nervous breakdown and self realization that the enemy she has been fighting is staring her in the eyes the whole time. Must see.
-Yuji in a different form,with a new plan in mind on how to release Shana from her Flame Haze duties. But will she beckon to this call?


-Conclusion to an amazing story, that has been tense for two seasons.



The Biggest Changes:


-More Bal Masque scenes, since Yuji is now on their side.


-Feels like the series evolved because of the dark theme.


-Shana is stronger, and now changing in her attitudes on life.


-Shana is becoming more aware of who she is, and that her and the Flame Haze are one and the same. More angelic moments, that make her seem more than what she has been for the series.


-Conclusion of Shana/Yuji. 



This series made me cry many times, and feel for the characters. Shana is truly evolved from the beginning of the show -- she is not thinking with her battle sense, but with her heart. Her own friendships are at stake, and the Flame Hazes are changing in their own sense of what they are truly fighting for.




The Downside:


Yes, at times it does feel as if they are grabbing for straws for the plot. At times it seems it is a Bleach-like story, but it does show climax through the series. I enjoyed it, but sometimes I felt maybe the pacing was a bit rushed in the third season. The one season they did start to change the plot out of nowhere, and make it serious.


Fans may not like Yuji's newfound place as Snake of the Festival, and also may not like how there is little filler and straight plot. Sometimes the plot feels forced, as if the war is the prominent story and no little slice of life.


It isn't until episode 16-17 that the series does pick up, and start feeling more like the previous installments.


Shana's independence is a great addition to the show. Her own powers have grown, and it is nice to see our own Flaming Haired Burning Eyed Hunter evolve so much.


Never backing down from her stance, Shana never changes her perspective on how to go about things. That is why I love this series so much. The struggles she goes through show how much that she has never turned away from her role as a Flame Haze. I love the fact that this anime turned out so well, and had climactic moments that made you question what side you were truly on. Whether it be, Bal Masque or the Flame Haze side -- you are in for a treat to the conclusion of this gorgeous anime.

==SPOILER WARNING==
This review assumes the reader has seen the first two seasons of the show. Proceed at your own risk.
The first two seasons of Shakugan no Shana were a very enjoyable experience, and the final moment of Shakugan no Shana II (Second) left me with high hopes that the following season would do what so few anime strive for, which is to elaborate on the central relationship beyond the confession. Watching the OVA, which at first seemed to be nothing more than filler, I was soon informed that I may not be getting what I hoped for.
Shakugan no Shana III (Final) oddly strays from thepath that the prior seasons were building, a sudden and jarring step in the wrong direction. It begins with the disappearance of Sakai Yuji, a phenomenon soon explained to be because he had become one with the leader of Bal Masque, the Snake of the Festival. To have the main couple grow so close, only for such a thick wall to be thrown between them - they say conflict builds character, but an obstacle so great can only hurt their relationship, and that it did. Clear that Yuji had become the antagonist of his own will, he and Shana are torn apart. Despite their attempts to bring the other back to their own side, it's clear that they no longer have the same bond they once did, which greatly hurts the romantic appeal of the show. Even in the end when things finally seem resolved, Yuji's determination as the antagonist is sustained until the very last moments, stripping the conclusion of its satisfaction.


Yuji alone is not the only instance of poor choices this season makes. Characters who once seemed important are revealed to be nothing in the grand scheme. Ike's uselessness is brought to light by his major lack of presence. His true purpose in the show becomes clear: to stand between Yuji and Kazumi, whether it be to help them along or to try and take Kazumi for himself. Once he confesses in the second season, his purpose is fulfilled, and they rightly cast him aside. Similarly, Tanaka and Ogata's entire dynamic is thrown away. With Ogata's lack of presence, the entirety of Tanaka's character development disappears, and he reverts to the same grunt role he had in the first season. Of the human characters, the only two who continued to show promise were Kazumi and Satou, the former more than the latter.


Humans aside, (Final) has a terrible problem of throwing in Flame Haze and Denizens where they don't belong. The season introduces new characters on both sides whenever it gets the chance, making for a surplus of meaningless stand-ins to take hits and kill grunts. They have no time to grow on the viewer, and thus their emotional moments fall flat. It also makes for a few difficult moments keeping track of who's who.


Despite all these problems, though, (Final) was not as terrible as it could have been. It may have chosen the wrong path on which to end the series, but its journey down that path was handled rather well. The characters who still had purpose, and who the viewer had time to become attached to, were utilized in very exciting battles and emotional moments. The aesthetics were lovely, and as always the soundtrack was phenomenal.


All in all I feel that (Final) was an unnecessary ending to the series. It was not so reliant on information from the past seasons that it needed to happen the way it did, and the ambiguity between good and evil throughout left for an abundance of uncertainty and lack of satisfaction. Still, it did not fail to take what it had, no matter the quality, and make an overall enjoyable experience.

After totally marathoning all 3 seasons and Shana S, I can say that Final was probably the most mind bending cluster of useless fluff thrown your way. 
Honestly, story is pathetic and so is Yuji. The only thing that kept me going through the slog of background noise the series was the hope that we get to see why Yuji chose to do what he does, and its one of the most pathetic reasoning I've seen. Now, if this was the Yuji backin season 1 I would understand but clearly Yuji has regressed mentally for however much the anime overplays his "Strategic mind". 


I can't speak for those who've read the novel, but the anime gives just about 0 reason and it all boils down to, "I want to be next to Shana but I have an inferiority complex so I'm going to do some crap so I can leave a mark on the world"


It might be much to hope for but for roughly 70 episodes of content I can say that about 20 episodes worth of time that are totally useless and contrived. I guess it was a money thing. 


Shana Final just has so much that it tried to take that it did nothing well. I found myself more invested in the story of Satou, Tanaka, and Margery Daw than I was with Yuji. Nearly every side character (excluding Yoshida, because, well, shes Yoshida) was so much better. 


Honestly, seeing Shana's dere side is all that really motivated me.
